page.title: 15PUTTENHAM IN WORLD WAR II
page.content: During the war two bombs fell just outside the village and Lord Haw_Haw annouced that the Hog's Back airfield had been destroyed. There was no airfield and the bombs did no damage! But there was a platoon of over 120 men in the Home Guard and armed with guns and grenades they manned an observation post on the Hog's back. The area was important for agriculture and there was a machinery pool in the village run by S.W.A.C. Landgirls worked in the fields as did Italian prisoners of war from a nearby camp. Children, some as young as five years old, were evacuated from London to Puttenham. There was very little petrol for cars but plenty of buses, at least ten a day through the village. At night the A.R.P wardens made sure not a chink of light was showing.
